Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High Throughput Cryopreservation of Aquaculture Seed
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to advance cryopreservation technologies for the development of a seed banking product for commercially important aquaculture species. Genetic banking of plant cells, tissues, seeds, and embryos is common practice in agriculture to ensure important genetic lines are not lost due to disease outbreak or environmental catastrophe. However, genetic banking of embryos and larvae within the aquaculture industry is nonexistent to date, and the investments made toward genetic improvements are susceptible to catastrophic loss without a proper seed banking product. The inability to reliably preserve seed for long periods of time is currently a barrier to the formation of an aquaculture seed storage product. This research will enhance scientific and technological understanding for the cryopreservation of aquatic organisms and be a transformative step to protect genetic resources vital to the commercial aquaculture industry. These technological advancements also can be adapted for the conservation of threatened or endangered aquatic organisms important to food security and ecosystem health domestically and abroad.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a technology to implement a genetic banking product that allows aquaculture facilities to "cryobank" thousands of seeds from family lines developed over years of selective breeding programs. Recent advancements in rapid cooling for storage at liquid nitrogen temperatures (-196 degrees C) and ultra-rapid rewarming (~107 degrees C/min) have led to major breakthroughs in cryopreservation research. These advancements will be utilized to develop a low throughput, high efficacy strategy for the successful cryopreservation of an important aquaculture species, Litopenaeus vannamei or Pacific white shrimp. Protocol optimization for cryoprotective agent loading/unloading, vitrification, and ultra-rapid warming will result in high revival, survival, and grow out to post larval stages. Once proven, the technique will be scaled up to develop a high throughput process to successfully cryopreserve >10,000 samples per day. This technology will enable the commercial aquaculture industry to conserve important genetic strains and stockpile cryopreserved seed at the levels necessary to avoid interruptions to food supply commonly caused by disease outbreaks and environmental catastrophe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While research on the cryopreservation of marine shrimp has been limited in the last 4 decades, new methods in cryopreservation technology, and the large growth of shrimp as an aquaculture species, has brought more attention to finding a successful way to preserve them.  Successful shrimp cryopreservation would have a broad impact on the aquaculture industry, and the global food system by enabling innovation in selective breeding, and lead to further increases in the efficiency of shrimp aquaculture.  It would enable breeding experts to preserve specific genetic lines of shrimp developed through selective breeding over many years and enable movement of seed domestically and abroad without risk of disease transfer to partner facilities or customers.  It would also provide a platform for breeding programs to protect against loss of genetic improvements due to disease outbreak, environmental catastrophe, or mechanical failure.

 The main goal of this project was to successfully cryopreserve and develop a high throughput system for the economically important species, Pacific white shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei).  Prior to our Phase I research, it was discovered that the nauplius V stage larvae are better suited for cryopreservation as they exhibit a relatively high tolerance to chilling and cryoprotectant agents when compared to other embryonic or larval stages.  However, it was also observed that the increased complexity of nauplius V larvae may restrict effective cryopreservation as damage to the cuticle and organ systems responsible for molting and growth may be disrupted. This has likely restricted successful cryopreservation to date as the cumulative toxicity of the cryopreservation agents (CPAs) and the mechanical process of cryopreservation and rewarming dissociates the mechanisms responsible for molt.  Conversely, blastula stage embryos, while more susceptible to cryoprotectant toxicity and chilling injury, offer a less complex development timepoint which could offer an avenue for the first successful long-term survival of cryopreserved vannamei shrimp.  In blastulas, the organ systems responsible for molt in shrimp larvae have not differentiated which could make them better suited for recovery following minor damage from the processes associated with cryopreservation. Therefore, in this project, both pre-nauplii embryos and nauplius V stage larvae were pursued as an avenue for successful cryopreservation when coupled with vitrification and ultra-rapid laser warming.

Innovative warming strategies have opened the door to great advancements in recent cryopreservation research. The development of a technology which couples an infrared (IR) laser (1064nm wavelength) with plasmonically absorptive materials, such as gold nano shell particles, has enabled researchers to achieve previously impossible warming rates within cryopreserved material (>1.0 x 107 ?C/minute). Adapting procedures developed by previous researchers, an IR laser was used by Ecto, Inc in Phase I to try and achieve successful warming of vitrified larvae of Pacific white shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei).

To verify the optimum stage of embryos and nauplii for experimentation, several cryopreservation solutions were tested for toxicity effects using varied concentrations and exposure times. It was found that a combination of methanol, ethylene glycol and trehalose solution was the least toxic and the most effective in vitrifying the shrimp embryos. On the other hand, a solution containing methanol, propylene glycol and trehalose was found to be the least toxic and most effective for nauplii cryopreservation.   While novel results were achieved in improving the physical characteristics of the embryos that were warmed, and motility could be seen in warmed nauplii, there were never any larvae that survived beyond 24 hours. Alongside the biological research, the development of a ?pick ?n place? 3D printing methodology for droplet vitrification of CPA loaded shrimp larvae was developed to aid in increasing the overall throughput of shrimp embryo cryopreservation research. This automated printing platform will also allow the cryopreservation process to be scaled up to an industrial level once it has been optimized, and survival to molt is successful.

During Phase II, this project will focus on optimizing the vitrification and warming steps as well as in increasing the throughput to satisfy industrial demand.

As an initial go to market strategy, Ecto, Inc aims to partner with 1-2 domestic shrimp breeding programs for initial product demonstration at industry scale (10,000 shrimp/day).

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2021
Modified by: Kalliopi Loutradi - Rolenc
